projects.name: BUROW
projects.title: Burow
projects.description: What makes a place feel like a home? Burow is a desktop web application that helps people find the perfect neighbourhood to suit their needs. Focusing on livability metrics including price, walkability, and school rating, Burow makes it easy to discover the ideal location to complement your lifestyle.

info.title: Roles
info.content: Led design and development of results page. Co-led brand design. UX completed as a team.

info.title: Skills
info.content: UX engineering, web design, brand design, prototyping

info.title: Team
info.content: Aman Gupta, Emily Nguyen, Joel Sequeira

info.title: Design + Dev Tools
info.content: Sketch, Illustrator, HTML, CSS, Javascript, Node.js, React, API Linking

sections.content: When searching for a new place to live, popular real estate apps such as Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin first ask users for their desired location. Once selected, users can narrow down their results using metrics including price and number of bedrooms/bathrooms. Listings that catch the user’s interest can then be further researched in order to find their school rating, walkability, and more.

This user flow is intuitive for people who already have in mind a specific location they want to relocate to, however what if it were the opposite and you are trying to find the right neighbourhood for you?

To solve this problem, our team decided to reverse the user flow of standard real estate apps, allowing users to parse through neighbourhood data at a macro level. Our application sorts neighbourhoods within a city by the following criteria of price, walkability, and school rating. The variability of these metrics can be drastic, even in close proximity neighbourhoods. Because of this, this user flow benefits users who are unfamiliar with the city they are moving to.

sections.title: Storyboarding
sections.content: In order to empathize with our target users, we drafted two storyboards with possible scenarios within the scope of our application.

sections.title: Competitive Analysis
sections.content: Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin utilize picturesque real estate photography, clean visual lines and crisp typefaces to establish a professional, trustworthy interface. This gives them a sense of credibility and safety, however at the cost of appearing apathetic and stock.

To help us explore different approaches to our solution we prototyped mobile and desktop variants of our application. Our solution needed to give users similar functionality to popular real estate apps, so we included familiar features such as price search criteria and an interactive map.

The major difference in our solution is the focus of livability criteria in the search algorithm. To reflect this, we included visualizations that bring attention to neighbourhoods that best fit the user’s selected criteria. This way areas that are a ‘best fit’ are easy to pinpoint amongst all of the search results available to the user.

Because our application does not provide listings or connect users with online real estate agencies, our team decided to switch out the professional look for a cozy, welcoming atmosphere. To produce a homey feel, we followed a theme of burrowing animals and leaned towards warm earth tones and typefaces with gentle curves.

Redesigning a conventional user flow tested allowed me to test my understanding of the design process. Shifting the perspective of our target user from a micro-view to a macro-view resulted in a tool that my team and I did not invision at first. Despite this, we are satisfied with the solution our application provides. Through this project I also had another opportunity to advance my design skills, through themed branding, and development skills, such as working with React.js.

blocks.title: Objective
blocks.content: Design and develop a mobile web application focused on the principles of interaction design.

blocks.title: The Quantified Self
blocks.content: With the help of digital devices, we have an unprecedented ability to track our behaviors, habits, and thoughts. But turning data about ourselves and our communities into valuable insights is still remarkably difficult. My studio explored ways to support monitoring, reflection, and behavior change by collecting, consuming, and sharing personally relevant information. We considered how might we help people learn more about their everyday lives through self-tracking, and how might we help people draw insights from the mass of data they collect about themselves.

blocks.title: Who is Our Audience?
blocks.content: This section is currently under construction, check back later for updates!

blocks.title: Final Touches
blocks.content: Come check out the live prototype here!

projects.name: PORTFOLIO
projects.title: Portfolio
projects.description: Today’s professional atmosphere is more competitive than ever before. Being an undergraduate student who is applying to UI/UX design and engineering internships, I needed to have a website portfolio where I could display my projects and establish an online presence to potential employers. Building this portfolio would not only allow me to showcase my abilities as a designer and developer, but would also provide me an opportunity to apply the concepts and skills I have learned through my coursework and on my own time.

info.title: Roles
info.content: Sole web designer and developer. Fully contributed to design and branding process.

info.title: Development Tools
info.content: HTML, CSS, Node.js (Express + Handlebars), Sass, Gulp

info.title: Skills
info.content: Visual design, brand design, UI design, front-end development, back-end development

sections.content: To showcase my adaptive skillset by designing and developing my personal website portfolio.

As someone who grew up alongside the expansion of the internet, I have been exposed to countless examples of web design. There are multitudes of interfaces that I visit and interact with everyday, each with their own purpose, however I had to figure out what constitutes an engaging personal portfolio.

To begin exploring, I scrolled through portfolios created by experienced UI/UX designers and analyzed the design choices made for each one. Many URLs and mouse-clicks later, I began to get a feel for the unique brand identity each portfolio conveyed. A few in particular that stood out to me were rachel-schmitz.com , dorothywong.design and jonathanhowell.com. This is because of their clean aesthetics and professional, yet fun personality.

sections.title: Inspiration
sections.content: Before designing my portfolio, I decided search for more inspiration and dive further into my headspace. I knew that my portfolio would be a space for me to share my projects, but it is also a reflection of my identity and design style. With this in mind I collaged a moodboard of magazine spreads that balanced content in a bold and clean fashion. One of my personal principles is living a life in balance, and I thought these examples expressed the duality nicely.

sections.title: Mockups
sections.content: I truly think that a picture is worth a thousand words, and so I wanted my portfolio to focus on showing-not-telling my projects. To complement this idea, I designed my portfolio with an emphasis on graphics in order to illustrate visual storytelling. I decided to have my portfolio maintain a grayscale color theme with offset sections of text. This way images and colors capture the attention of the reader and guide them down each page.

As an aspiring developer, I thought it would be a great idea to push myself and build my portfolio from the ground up. Utilizing the knowledge of HTML, CSS, and Javascript from my coursework, I was able to develop my portfolio. In addition, I was also able to apply self-taught skills that I learned such as Sass, Gulp, and Node.js (Express + Handlebars). You can view my Github repo of this project here!

Challenging myself to build my portfolio from scratch allowed me to expand on my skills in visual design, UX design, and front-end development. Experiencing the design process firsthand on a project that represents my digital identity and capabilities as a designer and developer inspired me to delve deeper into understanding the potential impact designers have on the world.
